title: Farmer Wants A Wife to return in 2020 after bizarre online post
text:
It was one of the first reality shows featuring ordinary people looking for love.

And it seems Farmer Wants A Wife could be making a return to our TV screens.

On Wednesday, eagle-eyed fans of the show spotted one big change to their social media pages.

Bizarre post: Eagle-eyed fans noticed the official Farmer Wants A Wife Facebook and Instagram pages upload this photo on Wednesday

A new cover picture was uploaded to the Facebook page and was later posted on as their profile picture on the official Instagram account.

Fans of the once popular show couldn't contain their excitement and pleaded for the reality series to make a come back.

'Please come back! I loved this show!' one Facebook user wrote.

'Please come back!' Fans of the show are excited at the prospect of the reality show returning

'I miss this show soooooo much. Please come back!' one comment read.

And another added: 'This was the best of the reality TV shows...would love to see it return, in its original format.'

One of the success couples who fell in love on the show were Rob Hodges and Joanna Fincham.

They have since married and welcomed three children together: daughters Darcy, seven, and Maggie, five, and three-year-old son Roy.

Success story: Farmer Wants A Wife couple Rob Hodges and Joanna Fincham found love on the second season and have since married and have three kids daughters Darcy, seven, and Maggie, five, and three-year-old son Roy

Speaking to Mamamia on Wednesday, photographer Joanna gushed about raising her family on Rob's South Australian cattle farm.

'It really makes me happy, going out and helping on the farm. I love it,' she said.

'Maggie knows more than I do on the farm. The other day I said, 'Oh, look at the heifers!' And she said, 'Mum, they're not heifers. They've had babies.'' she quipped, adding that her youngest child Roy adores riding in tractors and jumping in the mud.

There have been no words if it will make a return, but we'll most likely find out at Channel 9's Upfronts.

The series first came to Australia in 2007 with Natalie Gruzlewski as host. It ran for eight seasons before it was canned. It was picked up again in 2016 but dismal ratings saw it axed again.
description: It was one of the first reality shows featuring ordinary people looking for love.
authors: David Wu For Daily Mail Australia
